item.title: Nomura Faces Rare Vote Over Shareholder’s Name-Change Proposal
item.description: Nomura Holdings Inc. has received a shareholder proposal that it will put to a vote for the first time in 13 years at a general meeting next month, as activism in the nation’s stock market heats up.
item.dc:creator: Takashi Nakamichi

media:content.media:description: Signage for Nomura Holdings Inc. outside the company's Otemachi head office in Tokyo, Japan, on Wednesday, Oct. 30, 2024. Nomura is scheduled to announce it’s second-quarter earnings figures on Nov. 1.

item.title: Asian Stocks to Rise as Optimism Fuels Wall Street: Markets Wrap
item.description: Stocks in Asia were set to track the biggest rally on Wall Street in more than two weeks as sentiment was boosted by a rebound in US consumer confidence, an acceleration of global trade talks and a global surge in bonds.
item.dc:creator: Rob Verdonck

media:content.media:description: The Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE) building, operated by Japan Exchange Group Inc. (JPX), in Tokyo, Japan, on Wednesday, April 9, 2025. Japanese stocks tumbled as concerns about US trade tariffs and wild swings on Wall Street sapped investor confidence, while the yen extended its rally.

item.title: S&P 500 Climbs 2% on Economic and Trade Optimism | The Close 5/27/2025
item.description: Bloomberg Television brings you the latest news and analysis leading up to the final minutes and seconds before and after the closing bell on Wall Street. Today's guests are Tony Rodriguez, Nuveen, Kai Haakon E. Liekefett, Sidley Austin LLP, Timna Tanners, Wolfe Research, Chad Tredway, JPMorgan Asset Management, Thomas Buckley, Bloomberg News, Holly MacDonald, Bessemer Trust, Ed Mills, Raymond James, Akayla Gardner, Bloomberg News, Sarah Green Carmichael, Bloomberg Opinion, Dana Telsey, Tesley Advisory Group, Doug Clinton, Intelligent Alpha, Jason Kelly, Bloomberg News. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: The Dollar’s Dominance Is Unwinding in Asia
item.description: On today’s Big Take Asia podcast: What an unwinding of the dollar’s dominance in Asia could mean for the region’s markets.
item.dc:creator: Julia Weaver, Rebecca Choong Wilkins, Yang Yang, Naomi Ng

media:content.media:description: A dealer counts US dollars at a money exchange market. Photographer: Asif Hassan/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: US 30-Year Yield Falls Most Since March as Investors Lured Back
item.description: Browbeaten long-bond investors got some relief on Tuesday as a global debt rally sent benchmark yields tumbling.
item.dc:creator: Alice Atkins, Ruth Carson, Masaki Kondo

media:content.media:description: The US Treasury in Washington, DC.

item.title: Motorola Agrees to Acquire Radio Maker Silvus for $4.4 Billion
item.description: Motorola Solutions Inc. has agreed to buy closely held wireless-radio maker Silvus Technologies Inc. from TJC for $4.4 billion in its second-biggest acquisition.
item.dc:creator: Liana Baker, Ryan Gould, David Carnevali

media:content.media:description: Motorola signage during a media preview event in New York, US, on Wednesday, April 23, 2025. Lenovo Group Ltd.'s Motorola brand launched a new Razr foldable phone lineup loaded with a suite of artificial intelligence assistants in a far-reaching overhaul of its portfolio that also includes new earbuds and a watch. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: Musk to Tell SpaceX Workers About His Mars Plans
item.description: Elon Musk is scheduled to hold an all-hands meeting with SpaceX workers to address plans for reaching Mars. Bloomberg’s Loren Grush discusses what is expected with Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on "Bloomberg Technology." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: iPhone Tariff Threat Weighs on Apple
item.description: It’s a “fairytale” to think the full iPhone supply chain can be moved to the U.S., says Carolina Milanesi, president and principal analyst at Creative Strategies. She speaks with Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on "Bloomberg Technology." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Zuckerberg’s Bet on MAGA Has Yet to Pay Off for Meta
item.description: Mark Zuckerberg has gotten close with President Trump and the White House, but those ties have yet to bear fruit for his social media company, Meta. Bloomberg’s Riley Griffin discusses her latest Big Take with Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on "Bloomberg Technology." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Rigetti Founder Launches New Quantum Firm to Boost AI
item.description: Chad Rigetti says his new startup, Sygaldry, will stand out from competitors in the quantum space because those rivals formed their business roadmaps years before AI was widely adopted. Rigetti speaks about his Y Combinator–backed company with Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on "Bloomberg Technology." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Aramco Raises $5 Billion in Year’s First Dollar-Bond Sale
item.description: Saudi Aramco sold its first dollar-bond sale of 2025 on Tuesday, a $5 billion deal as the world’s biggest oil exporter looks to leverage its balance sheet.
item.dc:creator: Olga Voitova

media:content.media:description: Aramco’s net debt rose to the highest in almost three years in the first quarter. Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg

item.title: Banks Considering A Role in Stablecoin
item.description: Banks are considering a role in stablecoins if US legislation passes this year. Companies owned by Bank of America, Citigroup, JPMorgan and Wells Fargo have discussed jointly issued coins, according to the Wall Street Journal. Bloomberg's Michael Regan reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: S&P 500 Climbs on Eco & Trade Optimism | Closing Bell
item.description: Comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the U.S. market close on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Romaine Bostick, Alix Steel, Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Canadian Aluminum Trader Blames Its Bankruptcy on Trade War
item.description: A Canadian aluminum trader that had been struggling to restructure its debt has filed bankruptcy in the US and Canada, saying the American trade war helped push the company over the edge.
item.dc:creator: Steven Church

media:content.media:description: Cut aluminium signs at a manufacturing facility in Langford, British Columbia.

item.title: Biotech IPO Slump Seen Dragging Into 2026 as Returns Disappoint
item.description: Drug developers aren’t expected to come back to the US equity markets in full force until next year — lagging other industries as biotechnology has delivered only subpar investor returns.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Hughes

media:content.media:description: Tablets move along a conveyor on the production line in the packaging unit of the Laurus Labs Ltd. factory in Visakhapatnam, India, on Saturday, March 19, 2022. On the edge of Hyderabad in southern India, a vast patch of arid shrub-land the size of about 14,000 football fields is becoming a testing ground for a model that could help wean the world off its dependence on Chinese drug ingredients.

item.title: Apple Shares Face More Pain as Trump’s Tariff Threat Looms
item.description: Apple Inc. shares are coming off their longest selloff in more than three years, as escalating attacks from the White House threaten to further erode the company’s profit outlook, suggesting the stock’s struggles this year are far from over. President Donald Trump on Friday threatened to levy a 25% tariff on the company’s products if it doesn’t shift iPhone production to the US. Shares fell 3% to end the week, their eighth straight negative session, the longest such selloff since January 2022. The stock rose 1.7% on Tuesday. Some analysts are skeptical that the tariffs will come to pass, but any movement in this direction will put the company in a position where it either has to absorb the higher costs, weighing on its earnings and margins, or pass along higher prices to consumers, which could erode demand at a time when Apple is already struggling with tepid growth and difficulties with its artificial intelligence offerings. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: US Stocks Rally on Easing Tension With EU, Consumer Confidence
item.description: US stocks gained after a long holiday weekend on signs of cooling trade tensions between the US and the European Union, rebounding consumer confidence and falling bond yields.
item.dc:creator: Joel Leon

media:content.media:description: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.

item.title: S&P 500 Climbs 2% on Economic and Trade Optimism: Markets Wrap
item.description: Wall Street kicked off the week with a rally in stocks as consumer confidence rebounded sharply while the US and the European Union sped up trade talks. A global surge in bonds also helped sentiment.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

item.title: Defaults Put Spotlight on Brazil Bank Behemoth’s Agro Dependence
item.description: Banco do Brasil SA’s dominance in agribusiness loans has often been touted as a key strength. The bank accounts for half of the financing that flows into the sector — an edge in a country that, by and large, feeds the world breakfast.
item.dc:creator: Giovanna Bellotti Azevedo, Martha Viotti Beck, Rachel Gamarski

media:content.media:description: A worker prunes coffee plants affected by drought at the Rosario farm in Pedregulho, Sao Paulo, Brazil, on Wednesday, Sept. 18, 2024.

item.title: GOP Push Weakens US EV Market: Bloomberg's Denning
item.description: Sales of EVs, including plug-in hybrids, almost quintupled during the first three years of former President Joe Biden’s administration, according to figures from New AutoMotive, a UK-based research firm. The House tax bill though is a maximalist assault on EV subsidies. Bloomberg Opinion Columnist Liam Denning believes that deeper challenges lie ahead for the EV industry. He speaks with Vonnie Quinn on "Bloomberg Markets." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Harvard Set to Lose All Federal Contracts
item.description: President Donald Trump’s administration is moving to cancel all remaining federal contracts with Harvard University, marking the latest escalation of its battle against the oldest and richest US school. Bloomberg's Brooke Sutherland has more on the story. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Stablecoin Bill on Path to Passage After Senate Vote
item.description: A 66-32 Senate vote on May 19 advancing the GENIUS Act, a bill that would bring a regulatory framework for stablecoin issuers, clears one of the major hurdles the bill has before its eventual passage. Bloomberg Intelligence Senior Government Analyst Nathan Dean has more on the story. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Salesforce Reaches an $8 Billion Deal to Buy Informatica
item.description: Salesforce Inc. has agreed to buy Informatica Inc. for about $8 billion, sealing the deal on a software firm that had seen its shares plunge by as much as 59% since the companies’ first talks failed last year. Informatica shareholders are set to receive $25 in cash per share, according to a statement on Tuesday, representing a 30% premium over its closing price on Thursday, before Bloomberg News reported that Salesforce and Informatica were in advanced talks. Salesforce said it expects the deal to close early in its fiscal year 2027. The company plans to fund the transaction through a combination of cash and new debt. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: State Street Files for Second Private-Debt ETF as First Fund Stalls
item.description: State Street Corp. is set to double down on its bid to bring private assets to a broader spectrum of investors, even as its initial ETF experiment in this area has struggled to gain momentum.
item.dc:creator: Emily Graffeo

media:content.media:description: State Street Financial Center in Boston, Massachusetts, US, on Wednesday, July 12, 2023. State Street Corp. is scheduled to release earning figures on July 14. Photographer: Vanessa Leroy/Bloomberg

item.title: Oil Declines as OPEC+ Supply Meeting Overshadows EU Trade Thaw
item.description: Oil slipped as the looming prospect of another major OPEC+ production increase overshadowed easing trade tensions between the European Union and the US.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis, Alex Longley

media:content.media:description: A tank at the Burnaby Terminal in Burnaby, British Columbia, Canada, on Saturday, Feb. 24, 2024. With an expansion of the Trans Mountain crude pipeline set to start operation in the months ahead, the supply of western Canadian oil available for export is set to rise by about 500,000 barrels a day by the end of next year, S&P Global estimates. Photographer: Paige Taylor White/Bloomberg

item.title: Long Munis Suffer on Tariff and Tax Fear as Short Bonds Gain
item.description: Muni investors seeking nearly instant gratification are being rewarded for their eagerness.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Singh

item.title: Consumer Confidence Jumps Most in 4 Years | Bloomberg Markets 5/27/2025
item.description: "Bloomberg Markets" follows the market moves across every global asset class and discusses the biggest issues for Wall Street. Today's guests; Bloomberg's Michael McKee, Liam Denning, Brooke Sutherland, and Ed Ludlow. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Galderma Backers Lead $4.13 Billion Rush of Europe Stock Sales
item.description: A trio of shareholders in Galderma Group AG are spearheading a flurry of stock sales on Tuesday involving European companies that could raise more than $4.13 billion combined.
item.dc:creator: Pablo Mayo Cerqueiro

item.title: ‘Widow Maker’ Bond-ETF Trade Delivers Fast Gains for Dip Buyers
item.description: Dip buyers in the dangerous world of long-dated Treasury debt are enjoying a rare pay day.
item.dc:creator: Isabelle Lee, Ye Xie

item.title: Founders Fund Backs Bulgarian Satellite Manufacturer
item.description: EnduroSat, a Bulgarian satellite manufacturer, has raised €43 million ($49 million) in a funding round led by Peter Thiel’s Founders Fund. Raycho Raychev, EnduroSat CEO and co-founder, and Delian Asparouhov, partner at Founders Fund, discuss why Bulgaria is becoming a hub for space firms with Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology.” (Source: Bloomberg)
